intro: Anisopappus anemonifolius, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It features basal leaves that are deeply lobed, resembling those of an anemone, and is characterized by its yellow composite flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant produces small, fluffy seeds that are dispersed by the wind, a common adaptation in arid environments. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is drought-tolerant, making it well-suited to desert conditions. Its botanical structure supports its role as a pioneer species in disturbed or degraded habitats.
